page.title: 08Industry: Tin & Copper Mines
page.content: The remains of lots of mines can be seen over most of Cornwall and our area has several - Trumpet and Wendron Consols was a large mine. In the 19th Century mining was a booming industry, but then things died down, mines closed and many Cornish miners moved to other countries. The only light which the old miners had to work by was a candle stuck into their felt hat. They had to work very long hours for very little pay: Â£1.40 a month. Women, called Bal Maidens, worked at the surface crushing the ore. Boys went underground at eleven years old. Now, in the 1980s, mining is much safer: the miners have electric lights and powerful drills driven by compressed air. Machines crush the ore instead of Bal Maidens.
